name: Sarah
bio:
**Sarah Walker**  [OLY](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OLY "OLY")  (born 10 July 1988) is a New Zealand  [BMX racer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMX_racing "BMX racing")  of  [Māori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people "Māori people")  and European descent. A competitor at the  [2008](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics")  and  [2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics"), she won silver in the  [Women's BMX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycling_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_BMX "Cycling at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Women's BMX")  at the latter event. Missing out on selection for the  [2016 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics "2016 Summer Olympics")  due to injury, she was elected onto the  [IOC Athletes' Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOC_Athletes%27_Commission "IOC Athletes' Commission")  during those Games.

## Private life

Walker was born in  [Whakatane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whakatane "Whakatane")  in the Bay of Plenty, and grew up in nearby  [Kawerau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kawerau "Kawerau").[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-Kawerau-2)  Of Māori descent,[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-3)  she attended Kawerau South School[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-Kawerau-2)  and  [Trident High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trident_High_School "Trident High School")  in Whakatane.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-4)

## BMX career

Walker took up BMX due to sibling rivalry; she wanted to be able to do what her younger brother could do, and do it better than him.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  In the 2008 season  [UCI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Cycliste_Internationale "Union Cycliste Internationale")  Rounds, Walker won seven races, came second in one race and didn't race two races. She was ranked number one in the world by the UCI in 2008,[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-6)  and was one of the favourites to win the  [BMX women's event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycling_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_BMX "Cycling at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Women's BMX")  at the  [2008 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics")  in  [Beijing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing "Beijing"), in the end she finished fourth.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  Walker has won a total of twelve New Zealand 20" titles from 1999 to 2011.

On 25 July 2009, Walker won the BMX World Championship in  [Adelaide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adelaide "Adelaide"), Australia in both the Elite Women and the Elite Cruiser Women events.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-Stuff.co.nz_2674158-7)[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-NZ_Herald_10586844-8)

At the 2010 BMX World Championship in  [Pietermaritzburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pietermaritzburg "Pietermaritzburg"),  [South Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa"), Walker finished second in the Elite Women's event, with first place going to  [Shanaze Reade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanaze_Reade "Shanaze Reade"). A crash during the Elite Cruiser event meant that Walker was not able hold on to her 2009 championship title.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-Stuff.co.nz_3979377-9)

In 2011, Walker made the podium in three out of four World Cup events to win the overall World Cup title, winning the Papendal Supercross in the Netherlands, second at the Test Event in London and third in South Africa. The fourth event was in USA where she finished sixth.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

At the 2012 Supercross in Norway, Walker dislocated her shoulder, which almost put her out of contention for the Olympics in London. After six weeks, she had to qualify for the Olympics at the World Championships in  [Birmingham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birmingham "Birmingham"), England where she did so with a fifth place in the semi final.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-10)

At the September  [2014 UCI BMX Supercross World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_UCI_BMX_Supercross_World_Cup "2014 UCI BMX Supercross World Cup")  race in California, Walker had a fall and suffered a serious head injury.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-11)  Whilst her helmet cam recorded her calmly giving detailed accounts to medical staff of what happened to her, she has no recollection of the entire day. She had daily headaches for the next six weeks, and it was five months before she received medical clearance.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  As of February 2016, Walker has experienced a total of 15 fractures during her BMX career.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-12)

As well as competing in BMX events around the world, Walker has also been the marketing face for Beef + Lamb New Zealand since 2008.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-13)  She is a sponsored rider for  [Avanti Bikes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avanti_(bicycle_manufacturer) "Avanti (bicycle manufacturer)"), using their line of ABD BMX bikes when racing.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-Avanti_profile-1)

### Olympic career

Walker wanted to become an Olympic athlete ever since watching New Zealand swimmer  [Danyon Loader](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danyon_Loader "Danyon Loader")  receiving his gold medals at the  [1996 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimming_at_the_1996_Summer_Olympics "Swimming at the 1996 Summer Olympics").[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  She was about to start track cycling and quit BMX when it was announced as an Olympic sport for the  [2008 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics")  in  [Beijing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing "Beijing"),[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  and this was the first Games she attended, competing in the  [women's BMX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycling_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_BMX "Cycling at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Women's BMX"). In the medals race, she ran a time of 38.805, finishing fourth. In the same  [event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycling_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_BMX "Cycling at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Women's BMX")  at the  [2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics")  she got a silver medal, with a time of 38.644.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  She missed being nominated for the  [2016 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics "2016 Summer Olympics")  in  [Rio de Janeiro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro")  due to breaking her arm during training in February 2016.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-2014_head_injury-5)  During the Rio Games, it was announced that she had been elected onto the  [IOC Athletes' Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOC_Athletes%27_Commission "IOC Athletes' Commission"); whilst initially missing out to  [Yelena Isinbayeva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yelena_Isinbayeva "Yelena Isinbayeva"),  [president](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_International_Olympic_Committee "President of the International Olympic Committee")  [Thomas Bach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Bach "Thomas Bach")  proposed that Walker be added to the group.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-14)

## Sponsorship and advertising work

Walker is an ambassador for Beef and Lamb New Zealand, alongside other athlete ambassadors  [Lisa Carrington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisa_Carrington "Lisa Carrington"),  [Eliza McCartney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eliza_McCartney "Eliza McCartney")  and  [Sophie Pascoe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophie_Pascoe "Sophie Pascoe").[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Walker_(BMX_rider)#cite_note-15)
